Authors: O'Roarty B., Patterson D., McGreal S., Adair A.
Title: A case-based reasoning approach to the selection of comparable evidence for retail rent determination
Affiliations: Centre for Property Research, University of Aberdeen, St Mary's, King's College, Old Aberdeen AB24 3UF, United Kingdom; N. Ireland Knowledge Eng. Laboratory, University of Ulster, Shore Road, Newtownabbey BT37 OQB, United Kingdom; Ctr. Res. Property, Plan. Logistics, University of Ulster, Shore Road, Newtownabbey BT37 OQB, United Kingdom

Logistics, University of Ulster, Shore Road, Newtownabbey BT37 OQB, United Kingdom; Adair, A., Ctr. Res. Property, Plan. Logistics, University of Ulster, Shore Road, Newtownabbey BT37 OQB, United Kingdom
Abstract: Case-based reasoning is an artificial intelligence technique which utilizes past experience to solve current problems and in this respect it mirrors the process involved in real estate appraisal. This paper investigates its application as a computer-assisted valuation tool to the specific domain of retail rent determination. As property appraisal is goal orientated, it is essential that the most appropriate examples of previous rent determinations are selected. In exploring a case-based reasoning approach to the retail real estate domain five models are built namely; pure inductive, inductive (Q-model), inductive (prototype), inductive (Q-model and prototype) and nearest neighbour. © 1997 Elsevier Science Ltd.
Index Keywords: Computer applications; Economics; Problem solving; Value engineering; Case based reasoning; Comparable evidence; Retail rent determination; Artificial intelligence

Authors: Rowe J., Jewers K., Sivayogan J., Codd A., Alcock A.
Title: Intelligent retail logistics scheduling
Authors with affiliations: Rowe, J.; Jewers, K.; Sivayogan, J.; Codd, A.; Alcock, A.
Abstract: The supply-chain integrated ordering network (SCION) depot-bookings system automates the planning and scheduling of perishable and nonperishable commodities and the vehicles that carry them into J. Sainsbury depots. This initiative is strategic, enabling the business to make the key move from weekly to daily ordering. The system is mission critical, managing the inward flow of commodities from suppliers into J. Sainsbury's depots. The system leverages AI techniques to provide a business solution that meets challenging functional and performance needs. The SCION depot-bookings system is operational, providing schedules for 22 depots across the United Kingdom. Copyright © 1996, American Association for Artificial Intelligence. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Administrative data processing; Automation; Marketing; Performance; Scheduling; Strategic planning; Business process automation system; Depot bookings system; Retail logistics; Supply chain integrated ordering network; Artificial intelligence

Authors: Baron S., Lock A.
Title: The challenges of scanner data
Source title: Journal of the Operational Research Society
Affiliations: The Manchester Metropolitan University, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Baron, S., The Manchester Metropolitan University, United Kingdom; Lock, A., The Manchester Metropolitan University, United Kingdom
Abstract: Data capture at point of sale, using laser scanning technology, is now commonplace in retail outlets in developed economies. The volume of data collected is enormous (a single UK grocery superstore carries over 15000 different lines, each with a unique 13 digit barcode and will sell 600000 items per week). It has been recognized that, where point of sale data can be translated into meaningful information, there is scope for efficiency savings and exploitable competitive advantage. In UK grocery retailing the uses of scanner data have concentrated on operational aspects such as improved ordering systems and staff scheduling. There have, however, been many recent studies, predomi­nantly in the USA, which have examined, using scanner data, the relationship between marketing variables (price, display, advertising, coupons, and other promotions) and customer purchasing behaviour. This paper presents an overview of these studies and identifies the opportunities for operational researchers to further the understanding of such relationships through modelling and data handling. © 1995 Operational Research Society Ltd.
Author Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Marketing; Retailing
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Bar codes; Competition; Computer simulation; Data acquisition; Data handling; Information management; Laser applications; Operations research; Purchasing; Scanning; Scheduling; Laser scanning; Retailing; Scanner data; Marketing

Authors: Moutinho L., Curry B., Davies F.
Title: Comparative Computer Approaches to Multi-Outlet Retail Site Location Decisions
Affiliations: Cardiff Business School, University of Wales, College of Cardiff, Aberconway Building, Colum Drive, Cardiff CF1 3EU, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Moutinho, L., Cardiff Business School, University of Wales, College of Cardiff, Aberconway Building, Colum Drive, Cardiff CF1 3EU, United Kingdom; Curry, B., Cardiff Business School, University of Wales, College of Cardiff, Aberconway Building, Colum Drive, Cardiff CF1 3EU, United Kingdom; Davies, F., Cardiff Business School, University of Wales, College of Cardiff, Aberconway Building, Colum Drive, Cardiff CF1 3EU, United Kingdom
Abstract: This article explores alternative changes that could take place in the technology, methodology, and most importantly, the practice of locational decision-making, and is part of a larger scale project aimed at investigating the practical value of artificial intelligence (AI) techniques for strategic decision-making. The research involves comparing the effectiveness of a number of AI paradigms and modelling devices, both with each other and with more conventional computer models. © 1993, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Authors: McIntyre S.H., Achabal D.D., Miller C.M.
Title: Applying case-based reasoning to forecasting retail sales
Affiliations: J.C. Penney Research Professor Santa Clara University Santa Clara, CaliforniaUSA; L.J. Skaggs Distinguished Professor and Director of the Retail Management Institute, Santa Clara University Santa Clara, CaliforniaUSA; Assistant Professor of Administrative Science Jesse H. Jones Graduate School of Administration Rice University Houston, TexasUSA
Authors with affiliations: McIntyre, S.H., J.C. Penney Research Professor Santa Clara University Santa Clara, CaliforniaUSA; Achabal, D.D., L.J. Skaggs Distinguished Professor and Director of the Retail Management Institute, Santa Clara University Santa Clara, CaliforniaUSA; Miller, C.M., Assistant Professor of Administrative Science Jesse H. Jones Graduate School of Administration Rice University Houston, TexasUSA
Abstract: This article describes the development and testing of a forecasting system for retailers who plan periodic promotions. When the number of variables describing the promotion is large relative to the historical database of past promotions, traditional forecasting approaches cannot be applied. In such cases, retailers must rely on the expertise of their buyers to subjectively estimate promotional unit sales. This research develops a Case-Based Reasoning system that allows all buyers to forecast promotional sales as accurately as the organization's expert buyer and, by making the subjective process explicit, also provides an avenue to improve forecast performance over time. The system (1) selects the historical analogs that are most similar to the planned promotion, (2) adjusts the sales of each analog to account for any differences between the analog and the planned promotion, and (3) combines the forecasts derived from the multiple analogs to arrive at a single sales projection. The performance of the system was tested and found to compare favorably to the performance of an expert buyer in a large national retail organization. © 1993.
Author Keywords: Analog; Artificial Intelligence; Case-Based Reasoning; Combining Forecasts; Forecasting; Promotion Planning; Retail Industry

Authors: Murdoch H.
Title: Choosing a problem — when is Artificial Intelligence appropriate for the retail industry?
Affiliations: Dept of Computer Science, Aberystwyth University, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Murdoch, H., Dept of Computer Science, Aberystwyth University, United Kingdom
Abstract: Abstract: Current methodologies for choosing problems suitable for implementation as IKBS's are not appropriate for the retail industry, due to singularities of the domain. In particular, they exclude from consideration a kind of system which uses Electronic Point of Sale (EPOS) data to structure unstructured managerial perceptions, but several examples of these systems have been successfully implemented. Methodologies may be more domain specific than they were thought to be, and may hold back implementations to an artificially imposed level of difficulty. Nonetheless, analysis of the level of structure found in a problem is useful, as it points out possible trouble spots, and Fuzzy/Complex analysis was felt to be the most suitable methodology for retail due to its manufacturing origins, clarity of purpose, and flexibility. Copyright © 1990, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Authors: Min H.
Title: A model-based decision support system for locating banks
Affiliations: College of Business Administration, University of New Orleans, New Orleans, LA 70148, United States
Authors with affiliations: Min, H., College of Business Administration, University of New Orleans, New Orleans, LA 70148, United States
Abstract: The proper location of branch-banks is critical to the success of the banking business. The major ingredients for deciding where to locate branch-banks are: growth rates of deposits and loans; degree of competition; easy accessibility, and operating costs of potential sites. These are often highly sensitive to socio-economic, demographic, and behavioral factors that are ill-defined and fuzzy in nature. Accordingly, the traditional normative approach alone cannot analyze the excessive location-related data associated with the external factors and cannot appropriately evaluate behavioral criteria for branch-bank sites. In order to overcome these difficulties, this paper develops an interactive fuzzy goal programming model embedded within a locational decision support system for branch-banks. To demonstrate the practicality of the proposed model-based DSS, it has been applied to establish real-world-like location scenarios for commercial branch-banks in Columbus, Ohio. © 1989.
Author Keywords: Decision support systems; Fuzzy multicriteria decision making; Retail location

Authors: Muttiah R.S., Thai C.N., Prussia S.E., Shewfelt R.L., Jordan J.L.
Title: EXPERT SYSTEM FOR LETTUCE HANDLING AT A RETAIL STORE.
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Univ of Georgia, Griffin, GA, USA, Univ of Georgia, Griffin, GA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Muttiah, R.S., Univ of Georgia, Griffin, GA, USA, Univ of Georgia, Griffin, GA, USA; Thai, C.N., Univ of Georgia, Griffin, GA, USA, Univ of Georgia, Griffin, GA, USA; Prussia, S.E., Univ of Georgia, Griffin, GA, USA, Univ of Georgia, Griffin, GA, USA; Shewfelt, R.L., Univ of Georgia, Griffin, GA, USA, Univ of Georgia, Griffin, GA, USA; Jordan, J.L., Univ of Georgia, Griffin, GA, USA, Univ of Georgia, Griffin, GA, USA
Abstract: An expert system prototype (LETTMAN) was developed to simulate the decision-making process of a produce manager in a retail store. Lettuce was the commodity studied and a produce manager served as the domain expert. From several interview sessions with the domain expert, a flowchart was developed to illustrate the decisions considered, and a knowledge base was created using the production rule language of the expert system shell Insight2 plus . Results of the study showed that quality determination, price adjustment, potential sales and inventory control were the primary decision areas. Evaluation of LETTMAN indicated the need to incorporate reasoning schemes other than confidence factors in modeling lettuce quality decisions.
Index Keywords: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE - Expert Systems; QUALITY CONTROL; INSIGHT 2-PLUS; LETTUCE HANDLING; RETAIL STORE; FOOD PRODUCTS
